intro: Dinebra divaricatissima, commonly known as the broad-leafed mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that primarily inhabits tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and typically attaches itself to host trees such as eucalyptus and acacia. The plant has small, oval-shaped leaves that are often clustered at the ends of its branches. Its flowers are usually greenish-yellow and are followed by small, fleshy berries that contain the seeds. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly impact the health of its host trees if left unchecked.
